clinical_study.brief_title: Safety of Heparin in Patients With Septic Shock
clinical_study.official_title: Safety of Heparin Anticoagulation for Prevention of Death in Patients With Septic Shock.

brief_summary.textblock: Sepsis is a syndrome comprised of a systemic inflammatory response, signs of tissue hypoperfusion, and organ in the setting of presumed infection. Heparin, in addition to being an anticoagulant, is also a well-known antiinflammatory. The investigators believe that unfractionated heparin has the potential to save the lives of septic patients at a drastically reduced cost. This is a dose escalation study to determine the safety of increasing levels of heparin in this patient population; compare markers of anticoagulation and inflammation between treatment groups; and compare clinical outcomes between groups.

clinical_study.why_stopped: Sara Cheng, MD has left the Univ. of Colorado and the study has been closed.

primary_outcome.time_frame: This outcome will be measured for an average of 30 days
primary_outcome.description: Defined as:decrease in hemoglobin greater than 2g/dl and/or transfusion of 2 or more units of packed red blood cells. However, if there are obvious other reasons for bleeding, such as within 12 hours of major surgery, coagulopathy unrelated to heparin or an anatomical basis.

arm_group.description: Patients 11-15: IV heparin, target aPTT range 40-50 seconds
Patients 26-40: IV heparin, target range aPTT 50-60 seconds
Patients 41-55 IV heparin, target aPTT range 60-70 seconds

arm_group.arm_group_label: sq heparin three times a day
arm_group.description: Patients 1-10 will receive subcutaneous heparin three times a day

intervention.description: intravenous heparin titrated to an aPTT of 40-50 seconds starting between 300-500 units per hour and adjusted every 6 hours based on aPTT, starting within 24 hours of ICU admission up to 6 days.
intravenous heparin titrated to an aPTT of 50-60 seconds starting between 300-500 units per hour and adjusted every 6 hours based on aPTT, starting within 24 hours of ICU admission up to 6 days.
intravenous heparin titrated to an aPTT of 40-45 seconds starting between 300-500 units per hour and adjusted every 6 hours based on aPTT, starting within 24 hours of ICU admission up to 6 days.
5000 units subcutaneously three times a day, starting within 24 hours of ICU admission up to 6 days.
intervention.arm_group_label: sq heparin three times a day
